element.name: Woar Wars by Windsockers, Multi-cache (3/4)

long-description.p: Shenick Island is the largest of the islands of Skerries and can be approached on foot at Low tide. It gets its name from the Irish ''Sionnach,'' meaning a Fox. Standing at one end of the island is a Martello tower.

In 1878, a ''war'' began between the farmers of Rush and the Landlord of Skerries, Ian Hamilton. The farmers had long gathered Seaweed, which grew plentifully around Shenick Island and was known Locally as ''woar,'' to use as a fertilizer for their crops. Hamilton was trying to impose a payment for each load of seaweed. To enforce this he built a wall to prevent the farmers reaching the Shore and blocked their route out to the island. The Rush men Retaliated by breaking down the wall. This began a legal battle, Which lasted until 1896, and it was fought with great bitterness Both in the courts and on the ground.

Hamilton claimed ownership of the shore and the islands because Letters patent, [documents from the government giving ownership], Were granted to the Earl of Thomond, from whom the Hamilton family Had bought lands of Skerries in 1721. The Rush men claimed that the Shore was owned by the monarch on behalf of the people. The case Dragged on for nearly twenty years and Hamilton eventually won it In 1896. From that date the farmers had to pay one shilling, 6ct in Today’s money, for each load of seaweed. This payment lasted until 1946, when the seaweed war, was almost a forgotten memory

You need to check local tide times for parts of this cache. Access to the coast is only available at Loughshinny or Skerries. Please do not attempt to access the coast from the road between these two places as you would have to cross private land and there would also be some dangerous scrambling involved.

p.i: You can check local tide times Here

long-description.p: Walking boots are a must and you may need wellies as well as coastal errosion has created some areas of difficulty and danger. Please be careful while scrambling on any seaweed covered rocks. In the winter months it is likley that a boat may be required.There are signs stating that you should not walk to the Islands but this does not apply to this Island.
To find this cache you will need to do the following:
At the above coordinates in the year that Hamilton died 18?? Take these two numbers and place a zero after them to form ABC.
How many years did he represent this county ?? Place a “3” after these two numbers to form DEF.
Coordinates for part 2 of this cache are N53 33.ABC W006 05.DEF.
The second half of the coordinates for the final cache are in a micro at this location. The first half is N53 34.269

p.b: If you wish to find the two other local caches in this series you will need to take careful note of the code provided in the final cache.

element.additional-waypoints:
FLWBCE - Final location
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___
P2WBCE - Part 2
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

ul.li:
2010-05-23T19:00:00Z : Found it by Jumpin Jiminie
Great cache!
I did the first part of this a few months back but decided to wait for some decent weather and make a day of it. Couldn't have asked for a better day!
Lots of sunburn, nettle stings and bramble scrapes but well worth it. The Seagulls were not too happy with us as we were walking fairly close to their eggs but I think they soon realised that it wasn't their treasure that we were seeking!
Thanks to Windsockers for a fantastic cache.
Jamie

2009-12-20T20:00:00Z : Write note by Jumpin Jiminie
Stopped off to get the info for the 2nd stage whilst I was in the area... Looking forward to the rest of it!

2008-07-27T19:00:00Z : Found it by EnigmaFish
this is - so far - my favourite cache! I was dying to go back to work that Monday, hoping someone would ask me, "So, did you do anything exciting this weekend?" so I could answer "Yes, I had a proper adventure! I waded over to an island in waist high water to look for buried treasure! And when we got to the island, I had to fight my way (in shorts) through nettles and brambles! But we found the treasure in the end!"
That was so much fun. I felt like a pirate!
Oh, also, I didn't take or leave anything at the cache but I did take a new little friend home with me... On 3 June 2006, 150,000 yellow rubber ducks were put in the Liffey for a race to win money for Our Lady's Hospital in Crumlin. On 27 July 2008, I found one lonely little duck, bleached white and sticky, waiting for me on the beach on Shenick Island...All the more remarkable when you consider that "The majority of the ducks were removed from the water at the race's conclusion by a fishing net and are being held in storage for the next Duck Race." (childrenslifeline.ie) [8D]
[This entry was edited by EnigmaFish on Thursday, January 15, 2009 at 3:51:05 PM.]

2008-07-27T19:00:00Z : Found it by Fjon
After having attempter this over two years ago, I decided to give it another go today. The weather was perfect, and the walk through the water was really pleasant. I wore some wetsuit booties, which perhaps wasn't the best thing to be wearing once I got to the island. The walk to the cache is pretty much the hardest thing about the cache. It's really overgrown, and full of nettles and brambles. I'd recommend going along the beach, which we did on the way back. Found the cache easily - looks like some ants have made it their home. This was a lot of fun - thanks!

2008-06-28T19:00:00Z : Found it by Duchodci
Yeeaaah, we have found this amazing cache. I strongly recommend it to all hunters. It was real adventure. We have done with our friends Petr and Kata. In: TB Out: TB Thanks to Stephen. MaJa

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Woar Wars
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The Sea Weed Wars

Shenick Island is the largest of the islands of Skerries and can be approached on foot at Low tide. It gets its name from the Irish ''Sionnach,'' meaning a Fox. Standing at one end of the island is a Martello tower.

In 1878, a ''war'' began between the farmers of Rush and the Landlord of Skerries, Ian Hamilton. The farmers had long gathered Seaweed, which grew plentifully around Shenick Island and was known Locally as ''woar,'' to use as a fertilizer for their crops. Hamilton was trying to impose a payment for each load of seaweed. To enforce this he built a wall to prevent the farmers reaching the Shore and blocked their route out to the island. The Rush men Retaliated by breaking down the wall. This began a legal battle, Which lasted until 1896, and it was fought with great bitterness Both in the courts and on the ground.

Hamilton claimed ownership of the shore and the islands because Letters patent, [documents from the government giving ownership], Were granted to the Earl of Thomond, from whom the Hamilton family Had bought lands of Skerries in 1721. The Rush men claimed that the Shore was owned by the monarch on behalf of the people. The case Dragged on for nearly twenty years and Hamilton eventually won it In 1896. From that date the farmers had to pay one shilling, 6ct in Today’s money, for each load of seaweed. This payment lasted until 1946, when the seaweed war, was almost a forgotten memory

WARNING!

You need to check local tide times for parts of this cache. Access to the coast is only available at Loughshinny or Skerries. Please do not attempt to access the coast from the road between these two places as you would have to cross private land and there would also be some dangerous scrambling involved.

You can check local tide times Here

Walking boots are a must and you may need wellies as well as coastal errosion has created some areas of difficulty and danger. Please be careful while scrambling on any seaweed covered rocks. In the winter months it is likley that a boat may be required.There are signs stating that you should not walk to the Islands but this does not apply to this Island.


The Cache

To find this cache you will need to do the following:

Part one

At the above coordinates in the year that Hamilton died 18?? Take these two numbers and place a zero after them to form ABC.

How many years did he represent this county ?? Place a “3” after these two numbers to form DEF.

Coordinates for part 2 of this cache are N53 33.ABC W006 05.DEF.

Part Two

The second half of the coordinates for the final cache are in a micro at this location. The first half is N53 34.269



If you wish to find the two other local caches in this series you will need to take careful note of the code provided in the final cache.



The Windsockers

Additional Waypoints

FLWBCE - Final location
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

P2WBCE - Part 2
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

After having attempter this over two years ago, I decided to give it another go today. The weather was perfect, and the walk through the water was really pleasant. I wore some wetsuit booties, which perhaps wasn't the best thing to be wearing once I got to the island. The walk to the cache is pretty much the hardest thing about the cache. It's really overgrown, and full of nettles and brambles. I'd recommend going along the beach, which we did on the way back. Found the cache easily - looks like some ants have made it their home. This was a lot of fun - thanks!
Yeeaaah, we have found this amazing cache. I strongly recommend it to all hunters. It was real adventure. We have done with our friends Petr and Kata. In: TB Out: TB Thanks to Stephen. MaJa
